Book.title: Book
Book.description: Represents a book in the BookSnap application.

publicationYear.description: The year the book was published.

description.description: A synopsis or description of the book.

coverImageUrl.description: URL of the book cover image.

genre.description: The genre of the book (e.g., Fiction, Science Fiction, Mystery).

User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the BookSnap application.

bio.description: A short bio for the user.

LibraryEntry.title: LibraryEntry
LibraryEntry.description: Represents an entry in a user's library, linking a user to a book and its reading status.

id.description: Unique identifier for the library entry.

readingStatus.description: The reading status of the book (Want to Read, Reading, Finished).

progress.description: The reading progress as a percentage (0-100).

Recommendation.title: Recommendation
Recommendation.description: Represents a book recommendation for a user.

reason.description: The reason for the recommendation (e.g., 'Based on your reading history').

Comment.title: Comment
Comment.description: Represents a comment or a reply posted by a user on a book's discussion page.

bookId.description: Reference to the Book this comment is about.

parentId.description: If this is a reply, the ID of the parent comment. Otherwise null.

userId.description: Reference to the User who posted the comment.

username.description: The username of the user at the time of posting.

userAvatar.description: The avatar ID of the user at the time of posting.

createdAt.description: The timestamp when the comment was created.

score.description: The vote score of the comment.

upvotes.description: A list of user IDs who have upvoted the comment.

downvotes.description: A list of user IDs who have downvoted the comment.

isSpoiler.description: Whether the comment is marked as a spoiler.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore data structure is designed to provide a secure, scalable, and debuggable solution for the BookSnap application, adhering to the principles of Authorization Independence, Clarity of Intent, DBAC (Database-Based Access Control), and QAPs (Rules are not Filters).

**Authorization Independence:**  Authorization independence is achieved by storing the `userId` within the LibraryEntry and Recommendation documents. This denormalization eliminates the need for `get()` calls in security rules to verify the user's ownership, enabling atomic operations (transactions/batches) and simplifies debugging.

**Structural Segregation (Homogeneous Security Posture):** The structure segregates user-specific data into subcollections under the `/users/{userId}` path, ensuring that all documents within those subcollections share the same security requirements, in particular, ownership by the specified user.

**Access Modeling (Standardization and Consistency):** Access control is modeled using path-based ownership. Each user has their own LibraryEntries and Recommendations stored under their respective user ID, enforcing private data access based on the authenticated user ID.

**QAPs Support:** The structure supports secure `list` operations by using path-based ownership. Rules can easily filter based on the `userId` to allow listing only the LibraryEntries and Recommendations associated with the authenticated user.

**Invariants:** The structure supports the integrity of ownership by explicitly storing the `userId` in each LibraryEntry and Recommendation, ensuring that the correct user is always associated with their data.
